definition: **noun / hi-fi motor tech.** A **direct-drive turntable whose motor speed is governed by a feedback servo loop**, improving rotational accuracy and torque. The servo mechanism continuously monitors platter rotation via an optical or magnetic sensor, comparing actual speed against a reference signal and making microsecond adjustments to maintain precise 33⅓ or 45 RPM. Introduced by Technics with the SP-10 in 1970, servo-controlled direct drive revolutionized broadcast and DJ applications by eliminating belt-slip and providing instant start/stop capability with unwavering pitch stability. The closed-loop feedback system compensates for stylus drag, external vibration, and motor cogging, achieving wow and flutter specs below 0.025% WRMS—superior to most belt-drive designs. High-torque servo motors deliver full platter speed in under one second, making models like the Technics SL-1200 the industry standard for club DJs from the mid-1970s onward. Modern implementations often incorporate quartz-locked reference oscillators and digital signal processing for even tighter speed regulation. Audiophile debate persists over whether servo systems introduce their own micro-corrections that affect musicality, though measurable performance remains exceptional.
etymology: Combines 'servo' (from Latin servus, 'slave,' referring to automatic control systems) with 'direct drive' motor technology. Term emerged in early 1970s Japanese hi-fi engineering literature as manufacturers developed feedback mechanisms for direct-drive turntables.
